On January 29, 2018, [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) officially approved [[David Beckham|David Beckham's]] expansion team in Miami.{{Cite news |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/01/29/miami-mls-expansion-team-begin-play-2020 |title=Miami MLS expansion team to begin play in 2020 |date=January 29, 2018 |access-date=March 28, 2019 |website=MLSSoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3361118/mls-finally-announces-david-beckhams-expansion-team-in-miami |title=MLS announces David Beckham's expansion team in Miami |date=January 29, 2018 |publisher=[[ESPN]]}} Since they began playing in the [[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern Conference]] in the [[2020 Major League Soccer season|2020 season]], the club has signed several high-profile players such as [[Blaise Matuidi]], [[Gonzalo Higuaín]], [[Sergio Busquets]], [[Jordi Alba]], [[Lionel Messi]] and [[Luis Suárez]]. The club garnered international attention prior to their founding because of club president and co-owner Beckham, and again in 2023 with the aforementioned signing of Messi on a free transfer. Following the signing, the club won their first major trophy, the expanded [[2023 Leagues Cup]], the North American competitions for the [[CONCACAF]] region, which also qualified the team to the [[2024 CONCACAF Champions Cup]] for the first time. The team's [[Forbes list of the most valuable MLS clubs|''Forbes'' estimated value]] is $1.03 billion {{as of|2024|lc=y}}, ranking second in the league behind [[Los Angeles FC]].{{cite news [[Miami]] expansion team led by [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[Marcelo Claure]], a Bolivian businessman based in the city, announced an expansion bid in October 2008, with plans to begin play in Additionally, MLS expressed concerns about Miami's lack of fan interest in an MLS franchise, the fact that [[United Soccer Leagues|USL]] team [[Miami FC (2006)|Miami FC]] was not doing well,{{According to whom|date=February 2024}} and the plan to use [[FIU Stadium]] relegating the team to a secondary tenant in a [[college football]] stadium with an artificial surface.{{Cite news telecommunications and construction company MasTec) four years after the ownership's original announcement of pursuing a team, was awarded the twenty-fifth MLS franchise and was set to launch in the The announcement represented part of a larger MLS expansion that would increase its number of teams to 26 by 2020 and 30 after that. Since Beckham's original announcement of his intention to place a team in Miami in 2014, [[Orlando City SC]], [[New York City FC]], [[Atlanta United FC]], [[Minnesota United FC]], [[Los Angeles FC]], and [[FC Cincinnati]] have all begun MLS play. Paul McDonough was hired as sporting director effective August 4.{{Cite web | title=Miami MLS hires Paul McDonough from Atlanta to be Sporting Director | author=Tom Bogert | work=MLSsoccer.com | date=August 2, 2018 | access-date=August 15, 2018 | url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/08/02/miami-mls-hires-paul-mcdonough-sporting-director | archive-date=August 16, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180816061724/https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/08/02/miami-mls-hires-paul-mcdonough-sporting-director | url-status=live }} The team's ownership group was later renamed Miami Freedom Park LLC. They announced Club Internacional de Fútbol Miami, shortened to Inter Miami CF, as the club's official name on September 5, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45419289|title=Inter Miami: David Beckham's MLS team is called Club Internacional de Futbol Miami|date=September 5, 2018|publisher=BBC|access-date=April 9, 2019|archive-date=September 6, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906040231/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45419289|url-status=live}} MLS returned to the South Florida area in 2018, when Inter Miami CF was announced. On January 29, 2018, the Miami Beckham United group, four years after the ownership's original announcement of pursuing a team, was awarded the twenty-fifth MLS franchise and launched in the 2020 season, playing on the site of Lockhart Stadium at the new [[Chase Stadium]]. Former Fusion coach [[Ray Hudson]] would go on to work as a color commentator for Inter Miami, while former Fusion player [[Chris Henderson]] is the club's current Sporting Director.{{cite news|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/01/29/its-official-major-league-soccer-awards-expansion-team-miami|title=It's official: Major League Soccer awards expansion team to Miami|date=January 29, 2018|access-date=January 31, 2018|website=MLSSoccer.com}}{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3361118/mls-finally-announces-david-beckhams-expansion-team-in-miami|title=MLS announces David Beckham's expansion team in Miami|date=January 29, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} The [[2019 MLS Expansion Draft]] was a special [[draft (sports)|draft]] for the Major League Soccer (MLS) expansion teams Inter Miami CF and [[Nashville SC]] that was held on November 19, 2019. They will continue to do so until their new stadium, temporarily known as [[Miami Freedom Park]], is completed.{{cite web|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article211712754.html|title=David Beckham's Miami MLS team might finally have a name|website=[[Miami Herald]]|access-date=August 20, 2018|archive-date=May 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180526114400/https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article211712754.html|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/22/sports/soccer/david-beckham-miami-mls.html|title=For David Beckham and Miami, a Bumpy Road Enters the Homestretch|last=Brenner|first=Steve|date=February 22, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 14, 2019|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=April 14, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190414225751/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/22/sports/soccer/david-beckham-miami-mls.html|url-status=live}} The project will include a 25,000-seat stadium that would form part of Freedom Park, a mixed-use complex on the former site of the city-owned Melreese Country Club near the [[Miami International Airport]]. Approval for construction of the stadium depended on the outcome of a public [[referendum]] held on November 6, 2018, and approval of city officials.{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Craig|title=Miami commission OK's referendum on David Beckham's MLS stadium plan|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/soccer/fl-sp-mls-stadium-referendum-hearing-20180718-story.html|newspaper=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=July 18, 2018|access-date=September 12, 2018}} The result of the referendum had roughly 60 percent of voters approving the measure to convert the city-owned golf course near the international airport into Inter Miami CF's new stadium.{{cite news|url=https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article220667190.html|title=Beckham scores key victory after voters endorse stadium plan in referendum|access-date=December 5, 2018|archive-date=November 16, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116063746/https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article220667190.html|url-status=live}} The whole project in total is worth over $1 billion.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/real-estate/commercial/miami-races-to-finish-350-million-soccer-stadium-before-messis-time-is-up-41cd41c2 | title=Miami Races to Finish $350 Million Soccer Stadium Before Messi's Time is up | newspaper=WSJ | last1=Acosta | first1=Deborah }} On August 20, 2019, Miami Mayor Francis Suarez confirmed a recent report that soil contamination at Melreese golf course, the proposed site for the stadium, was far worse than previously thought. According to CBS Miami, "...arsenic contamination levels are more than twice what is allowed by law. Barium and lead levels are also too high and there is debris in the soil that could cause physical hazards."{{cite news|url=https://miami.cbslocal.com/2019/08/19/mls-stadium-site-melreese-unsafe-levels-arsenic|date=August 20, 2019|title=Miami Mayor Confirms Proposed MLS Stadium Site Contaminated By Unsafe Levels Of Arsenic|work=CBS Miami|accessdate=August 21, 2019}} This has been approved by the results of a referendum in which 60% of the voters authorized the stadium. Also Miami-Dade Circuit Judge Mavel Ruiz's decision, preserved the results of a November referendum in which 60% of Miami voters authorized city administrators to negotiate a 99-year lease with the MLS team's ownership to develop Miami Freedom Park. The $1 billion stadium, hotel, office park, and commercial campus is to be built on {{convert|73|acre}} of city-owned land, currently Melreese golf course. The team would also build an adjacent public park. The MLS team, Club Internacional de Fútbol (Inter Miami), would play at least 17 home games annually in the 25,000-seat stadium. The development, being built on {{convert|131|acre|adj=on}} public land, will include {{convert|1000000|sqft}} of office, retail and commercial space, 750 hotel rooms, {{convert|23|acre}} of public soccer fields in addition to the {{convert|10.5|acre|adj=on}} stadium, and the remaining {{convert|58|acre}} will be a public park.
